headline.main: Predictions for Health, Science and Life

docs.lead_paragraph: In the early 21st century, we take for granted a pace of change that can leave the near-miraculous seeming unremarkable but also upend ways of life with little warning. Scientists, professors and others peer around the corner to offer their take at what might be coming next.
docs.snippet: In the early 21st century, we take for granted a pace of change that can leave the near-miraculous seeming unremarkable but also upend ways of life with little warning. Scientists, professors and others peer around the corner to offer their take at...

docs.abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column examines the question of why people go hungry in the world even though enough food is produced to feed everyone; contends that if equal resources were put into reducing waste, questioning the value of animal products, reducing overconsumption and actively promoting saner, less energy-consuming alternatives, people of the world could feed themselves in an environmentally sustainable way.
docs.lead_paragraph: The world produces enough food for everyone. So why do people go hungry?
docs.snippet: The world produces enough food for everyone. So why do people go hungry?

headline.print_headline: In Struggle With Weight a Century Ago, a Diet From Today
headline.main: In Struggle With Weight, Taft Used a Modern Diet

docs.abstract: William Howard Taft, United States' heaviest president, struggled mightily to control his weight a century ago, but new research finds that his weight-loss program was startlingly contemporary, and his difficulties keeping the pounds off would be familiar to many Americans today.
docs.lead_paragraph: William Howard Taft, the United States’ heaviest president, used a weight-loss program that researchers have found to be startlingly contemporary.
docs.snippet: William Howard Taft, the United States’ heaviest president, used a weight-loss program that researchers have found to be startlingly contemporary.
